item.title: Exit Bash
item.description: Exit, Bash! I wish I would have been told at the beginning of my journey: "Yes, Bash has some quirky behavior and yes, you can work around them. But unless what you are doing is either trivial or insignificant, you should really look for a better tool." And by trivial, as we will see, I mean not using conditionals, subshells, pipes or functions. I'm not considering Bash appropriate for writing any important application (you'd have to be insane to want to do that).

item.title: Netrw is the new nerdtree - Browse through buffers
item.description: After finding ctrl-p I thought it solved my navigation issues with vim. Additionally, it’s convenient to split a pane in tmux from within ranger and then continue with ctrl-p. George Ornbo showed a better way though: netrw instead of nerdtree It is better, because if you traverse towards the depths of the root of the filesystem, ctrl-p might hang for what seems like an eternity on my old Thinkpad (am I completing the stereotype?
